sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,"To Eliza." Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser (Charleston, SC), June 13, 1796

title.note: 1 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (June 13, 1796). Turnbull had previously used the name Eliza in "Pastoral," printed in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 26, 1796).

lg.l: From virtue if the virgin stray,
And yield her heart an easy prey
To the lewd voice of guilty love,
What can her infamy remove?
The youth intemp'rance may allure,
And riot mark his midnight hour;
Yet age and reason may controul,
The passions that debauch’d his soul,
And he, returning, fix his fame
Secure, and boast a spotless name;
But she, wrong’d maid, despised by all,
Can never once retrieve her fall!
Her life, in shameful pleasure spent,
Yields her no peace no sweet content;
The scorn of all the virgin train,
Her guilty footsteps they disdain;
By parents shun’d, by friends despised,
By none who boast their honor priz'd—
Even he who wrought her foul disgrace,
Disgusted, leaves her loath’d embrace:
Her youth is gone, her beauty flies,
In pain she lives, unmourn'd she dies!
No husband o’er her silent urn
Reclines, his faithful mate to mourn;
No father pays his pious care.
No weeping mother wanders there;
No friendly willows o’er her grave
Their drooping boughs in sorrow wave;
No pensive maiden deck her tomb
With true—love flow’rs of early bloom:
Near this sad place no tender dove,
In plaintive strains, laments her love:
But from the blasted leafless oak,
Owls scream, and boding raven croak;
Chaste love and honor fly the place
Where sleeps the object of disgrace!
Beware Eliza, then beware!
And eager than the subtil snare
Of man’s deceitful, honey’d tongue,
That lures the heedless and the young,
To follow pleasure’s flow'ry maze,
And lead the heart from Virtue’s ways:
A virgin’s fame’s her chiefest boast,
That gone, her peace, her soul is lost!
